It is often useful to isolate the method that uses Math.random(), and pass
the random number as a parameter. We can then test boundary conditions which
often tend to suffice.

e.g. Here's a method below that shuffles a deck of cards, by picking up a
random card at or after a position (i), and swaps it with the card at that
position (i).

public void shuffle() {
    for (int i = 0; i < cards.size() - 1; i++) {
        int randomPosition = (int) ((cards.size() - position) *
Math.random());
            swapCards(i, randomPosition);
    }
}

This method is very hard to test - so we could refactor the formula out,
like so:

public void shuffle() {
    for (int i = 0; i < cards.size() - 1; i++) {
        int randomPosition =
            getRandomPositionInDeckAtOrAfter(i, Math.random());
         swapCards(i, randomPosition);
    }
}

public int getRandomPositionInDeckAtOrAfter(int position, double
randomNumber) {
    return (int) ((cards.size() - position) * randomNumber);
}

It is now possible for us to test the latter method with boundary
conditions - represented by the two extremes that can be generated by
Math.random() - 0 and 0.99.

For the shuffle() method itself, a simple test that verifies that the new
order of cards differs from the original order was sufficient.
